children.name: to decide that a planned event will not now happen
cancel
children.definition: to change a previous arrangement, so that a meeting, concert, game etc that was planned will not happen: huỷ bỏ
examples: Classes were canceled for the day.
I forgot to cancel my doctor’s appointment.
They were forced to cancel the concert when the conductor became ill.
Our flight was cancelled.
I’m afraid I’ll have to cancel our meeting tomorrow.
You’ll just have to ring John and cancel.
RegisterIn everyday English, people often saycallsomethingoffrather thancancelsomething:
We’ll just have tocancel.➔We’ll just have tocall it off.

children.name: call off
children.definition: to cancel a meeting, game, or event that you have organized.Call offis less formal thancanceland is very commonly used in everyday English : hủy bỏ
examples: Linda decided to call the wedding off.
The game was called off due to heavy rain.
The game was called off due to heavy rain.
Linda may call the wedding off.

children.name: be off
children.definition: if an event or activity is off, it has been cancelled because of a sudden problem or change in someone’s plans :
examples: I’m afraid the party’s off. Nick won’t let us use his apartment.
Myers called me yesterday to tell me that the deal was off.

children.name: scrub
children.definition: UK informal to decide not to do something that you have planned because there is a problem:bỏ, huỷ bỏ
examples: We haven’t really got enough money for the trip -- let’s just scrub it.

children.name: shelve
children.definition: to decide not to continue with a plan, project etc now although it may be considered again at some time in the future : “xếp vào ngăn”, xếp xó
examples: The city shelved the project due to lack of funding.

children.name: shelve a plan
examples: I've had to shelve my plans to buy a new car, because I can't afford it at the moment.
Plans for a new stadium have been shelved for now.

children.name: to disturb sb so that they cannot continue what they are doing
disturb
children.definition: to stop sb when they are working, talking, or having a meeting, especially because you want to ask a question or tell them something: làm phiền
examples: Sorry to disturb you, but could I ask a quick question?
Try not to disturb your dad - he’s working.
Before closing the door to his office, he told his secretary that he was not to be disturbed.

children.name: interrupt
children.definition: to stop sb when they are working, talking, or having a meeting, especially because you want to ask them a question or tell them something: gián đoạn
examples: ▪Don’t interrupt - I haven’t finished yet.
▪ I’m sorry to interrupt your meeting, but may I speak with Michael for a moment?
▪ While I was giving my report, some guy in the back kept interrupting me every two minutes.

children.name: bother
children.definition: to disturb someone who is doing something, especially in a way that is annoying:quấy rầy, làm phiền
examples: Will you stop bothering me? I’m trying to watch a program.
Sorry to bother you, but could you help me one more time with the copier?
Don’t bother Ellen while she’s reading.
Danny, don’t bother Ellen while she’s reading.
Would it bother you if I put on some music?

children.name: bother sb about/with sth
examples: It didn’t seem worth botheringthe doctor about.

children.name: break sb’s train of thought
children.definition: to disturb someone so that they forget what they were thinking about: phá vỡ dòng suy nghĩ
examples: ▪The phone rang, breaking my train of thought.
▪ I sat very still, not wanting to break her train of thought.

children.name: to disturb an event or situation
disrupt
children.definition: to disturb a situation, system, event etc, so that it cannot happen or work in its usual way:phá vỡ
examples: Loud frogs are disturbing the sleep of local home owners.
It is thought that the intruder was disturbed by a barking dog.
The aim of the strike was to disrupt rail services as much as possible.
The protest disrupted the Democratic convention Saturday, nearly forcing its cancellation.
Moving schools frequently can disrupt a child’s education.
Hecklers repeatedly disrupted Duke’s news conference, calling him a liar and a fascist.
disruption [U] C1
The storm has caused serious disruption to road and rail travel.
disruptive[adj] C2 causing problems and preventing sth from continuing in its usual way : phá vỡ
disruptive to
Night work can be very disruptive to home life.
Mike’s parents thought I wasa disruptive influence(= a person who causes disruption ).
ways to handledisruptive pupils

children.name: upset
children.definition: /ʌpˈset/  to disturb a plan, situation, relationship etc, especially so that people feel confused or angry:rối loạn
examples: ▪Young children don’t like anything which upsets their daily routine.
▪ The closing of the plant threatens to upset the local economy.
▪ Rowan said this latest outbreak of violence could upset the peace talks.

children.name: break up
children.definition: break up a meeting/demonstration/march etcdeliberately disturb it or prevent it from continuing, especially in a violent way: phá vỡ
examples: Police broke up the demonstration with tear gas.
The conference was broken up by animal rights campaigners.
Breaking meetings up and harassing party members are just some of the tactics our opponents have used.

children.name: destabilize
children.definition: / destabiliseUK  to make sth such as a government or economy become less successful or powerful, or less able to control events : làm rối loạn, mất ổn định
examples: destabilization/destabilisationUK [ U ]

children.name: an attempt to destabilize the government
examples: The conflict destabilized the whole region.
Further increases in imports could destabilize the economy.

children.name: make waves
children.definition: informal to be very active so that other people notice you, often in a way that intentionally causes trouble : “tạo sóng”
examples: If a member of the Cabinet started making waves, the prime minister simply got rid of them.
